Fig. 1 Rayleigh distributions employed in the simulations. The smallest value was set at 0.75 nm because that was the x-coordinate of the corresponding datum depicted in Fig. 2 in Peuckert et al. [14] Fig. 2 Population of C 9 3 sites as a function of the size of cuboctahedral particles of an fcc metal. Open circles: exact results calculated by van Hardeveld and Hartog [17]; Solid line: Eq. (3). Dashed line: work function for Pt ( Φ = Φ ∞ + 0.5 / r / 1.75 nm [21]). Fig. 3 Parity plot comparing simulated C 9 3 -based turnover rates against measured turnover rates for the electrochemical reduction of O2. ○: integrals of the Rayleigh distributions for each particle size multiplied by the C 9 3 distribution and the factor, b; *: C 9 3 distribution sampled at the reported sizes of the particles, multiplied by the factor, b (i.e., the particle size distribution was assumed to be δ(r-rmeasured) instead of the Rayleigh distribution). Note the break in the y-axis: the deviation from the parity plot for the δ distribution is more than a factor of 10 at the larger particle sizes. Table 1 Examples of fiducial reactions. Reaction to be normalized Example of Fiducial Reaction Reference Selective oxidation (structure-insensitive) Oxidation of Methanol [24,25] Acid-catalyzed cracking (structure-insensitive) Desorption and Cracking of 2-propylamine [26] Partial oxidation of methane (structure-insensitive) Dehydrogenation of cyclohexane [27] Ammonia synthesis (structure-sensitive) Chemisorption of N2 [28] PERSPECTIVE Lies, damned lies, and turnover rates Robert S. Weber Institute for Integrated Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, P.O. Box 999, MS-IN K3-81, Richland, WA 99362, United States Institute for Integrated Catalysis Pacific Northwest National Laboratory P.O. Box 999 MS-IN K3-81 Richland WA 99362 United States Institute for Integrated Catalysis, Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, P.O. Box 999, MS-IN K3-81, Richland, WA 99362, United States Graphical abstract A Rayleigh distribution of particles exposing (1 1 1) surface populations is consistent with the particle size dependence of the turnover rates of the electrochemical reduction of dioxygen catalyzed by a platinum cathode. Keywords Turnover rates Particle size distributions Weibull distribution Michel Boudart This Perspective deals with a slice of the vocabulary of heterogeneous catalysis. The lurid title derives from a variously attributed epigram [1]. It strives to denote the inadequacies of the current state of metrology in heterogeneous catalysis; it is not intended to impugn experimenters who feel constrained by historical practice. Michel Boudart, popularized two terms related to the title: “turnover number” [2] and its prerequisite, “dispersion” [3]. He borrowed the first from enzyme catalysis [4] where biologists have long confounded counting the number of turnovers effected by an enzyme catalyst and the rate at which those turnovers occur [5]. Following the pioneering measurements of metallic surface area by Boreskov [6], Boudart devised the second term to describe the surface/bulk ratio of the metal in supported metal catalysts. Likely, he chose to use “dispersion” because particles that are present at low areal density (i.e., that are highly dispersed) frequently exhibit a high exposure: dispersion is the means to the end. Ultimately, he corrected the first term to “turnover rate” [7] and the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry [8] has deprecated the second term in favor of “percentage exposure”. The first is in general use by those who study heterogeneous catalysis; the second, however, not so much. Other authors in this issue will describe how to make the corresponding physical measurements; here I deal with why they should be made and with an extension to them that may help advance the field of heterogeneous catalysis. The measurements of exposure and rate per active center can be performed readily in the case of homogeneous catalysts that consist of identical, molecularly defined sites which can be tracked spectroscopically around a catalytic cycle. In heterogeneous catalysis, however, their evaluation is more difficult but essential. Fractional exposure provides a key metric for materials that are typically prepared by procedures more akin to l’art de cuisine than stoichiometric chemical syntheses. Normalization of reaction rates into turnover rates therefore affords a basis of comparison of results and materials across laboratories, across reactions, and across reaction conditions. The latter can help ensure that the reported kinetics represent intrinsic reaction rates [9–11], i.e., they are not contaminated by finite rates of mass or energy transport. While the analysis below deals only with normalization of catalytic rates involving supported metals, the discussion suggests a way to normalize rates for oxide- and acid-catalyzed reactions. Even if a heterogeneous catalyst contains a very narrow distribution of site activities, just knowing their average turnover rate and fractional exposure (or, equivalently, the average domain size) does not adequately characterize the material nor suffice to tie its activity to its structure. In heterogeneous catalysts, neither distributions of support/ligand effects nor distributions of induced heterogeneity (affinity of adsorption varying with coverage) are typically available from physical characterizations (e.g., microscopy, spectroscopy) or chemical characterizations (e.g., titration [12], thermal programmed desorption, steady-state isotopic transient kinetic analysis [13]). In principle, calorimetry can measure the effects of coverage but under conditions that may be unlike those employed at steady state. More subtly, the shapes of the particles, and thus the geometry of their surfaces, are not captured by exposure averaged across the particles in a sample. To illustrate the last point, I have reanalyzed the turnover rates reported more than 30 years ago from a venture into electrochemistry by Boudart and his group [14]. That study showed that the turnover rate of electrochemical reduction of O2 by Pt was structure sensitive—it depended strongly on the measured exposure of the particles, which was varied by changing the loading of the metal and the surface area of the support. Regrettably, that study did not present any further information about the shapes of the supported Pt particles nor even the distribution of their particle sizes. In lieu of those actual measurements, here I have assumed that the particle size distribution W(r) can be represented by a Weibull distribution (Eq. (1)), which has been used to model finely divided metals [15]: (1) W ( r ) = k λ 2 r λ k - 1 × exp - 2 r λ k r > 0 0 r ⩽ 0 The Weibull distribution has the convenient property that it only allows for positive particle sizes. I constructed a set of Weibull distributions (Fig. 1 ) whose means were adjusted by varying λ so as to equal the mean particle sizes reported Peuckert, et al. [14]. The shape factor, k, was fixed at a value of 2. That choice makes the distribution identical to a Rayleigh distribution, which describes uncorrelated and normally distributed, isotropic growth [16]. That value has been used in previous characterizations of collections of small domains of metal [15,16] and yields an adequate representation here, as will be shown below. Larger values of k create distributions that are narrower. The integrals were normalized by multiplying each by a factor, mi , such that the mass-weighted area under each distribution (Eq. (2)) equaled the mass fraction of the Pt in each member, i, of the series of catalysts employed by Peuckert et al. (2) M i = m i ∫ 0 ∞ W i r × ρ 4 3 π r 3 d r As a plausible, but admittedly speculative representation of the relevant geometry of the surfaces, I used the particle-size dependent population of C 9 3 sites for a cuboctahedron of a face-centered cubic (fcc) unit cell [17]. Those sites comprise the (1 1 1) plane in an fcc metal, which is the lowest energy facet [18] and therefore would be expected to predominate in thermally equilibrated particles. It is also an electrochemically very active surface [19,20]. It is unlikely that a particular geometry, such as a cuboctahedron, will persist across a large range of particle sizes. Rather, it is used here as a convenient surrogate for a geometry that generates unsaturated surface sites whose populations vary roughly with the square of the particle radius. To facilitate interpolation and extrapolation of the population of sites, the exact polynomials from van Hardeveld and Hartog [17], were fit to a simple power law expression in the particle radius, r (Eq. (3), Fig. 2 ): (3) C 9 3 r = 211 × r 2.16 The integral of the Rayleigh distribution for each particle size multiplied by that population of sites (Eq. (4)) closely tracked the particle-size dependent turnover frequencies reported by Peuckert et al. [14] over the 20-fold variation in particle sizes and turnover rates (Fig. 3 ). Remarkably, a single constant, b, sufficed to represent the rate per ostensible C 9 3 site presented by the particle size distributions for all the members in the series of catalysts. A plausible inference is that the activity of each particle stemmed not from the size of the particles but rather from a particular type of site they presented, perhaps the assumed C 9 3 sites or, at least, a feature whose particle-size dependent population paralleled their exposure. If the particle size distributions were instead represented not by Rayleigh distributions but rather by δ functions centered at the reported particle sizes, δ(r-rmeasured), then the comparison between estimated and measured turnover rates was close only for the smallest particles (left-most points in Fig. 3), whose particle size distributions were narrow by construction. (4) TO F i = b ∫ 0 ∞ m i M i d × C 9 3 r d r The goal of this exercise is not the happy coincidence of measured and simulated turnover rates presented in Fig. 3. Evidently, the close correlation represented by the open symbols depends sensitively on both assumptions—that the particle size distributions could be modeled by Weibull distributions (with k = 2) and that the kinetically significant sites tracked with the population of C 9 3 sites. For example, the populations of other high-coordination surface sites also increase quadratically with particle size [17]. As with all of kinetics modeling, correlation does not imply causation. On the contrary, electronic features, e.g., work function, begin to asymptotically decrease with increasing particle size at the higher values of r depicted in Figs. 1 and 2 [21,22]. Therefore, collective “electronic effects” alone are not consistent with the observed trends in reaction rates with particle size. Rather, the goal is to motivate the more routine reporting of detail beyond percentage exposure. Of course, particle size distributions will depend on the conditions under which the catalyst samples are used and therefore static, pre-natal and post-mortem characterizations may not suffice. As in all of metrology, precise, accurate determination of distributions of particle sizes and shapes will involve successive approximations. But we will never succeed if we never start. Even if we could devise characterizations that assayed the distributions of particle sizes and shapes, we would still need to contend with the possibility that the active sites may be rare [23], and, of course, dependent on the reaction catalyzed [4]. A more faithful, if less simply interpreted, measure would be the use of an ancillary, standard reaction that would sample the sites of interest and whose reaction rate would be proportional to their number. I have introduced the term fiducial reaction for that measure for normalizing the rates of reactions closely related to the fiducial reaction (Table 1 ). It would be valuable to see whether such an approach could be devised to normalize the rates of reactions whose kinetics depend on the formation of ensembles of sites. In that vein, chemisorption of N2 does appear to titrate the active sites in Fe-based ammonia synthesis catalysts [28], presumably because dissociative adsorption of N2 is rate limiting in both processes. An extrapolation is that all catalytic reactions become structure insensitive, if one can normalize the rate by the critical structure. In this volume, Marin, et al. [29] compare two methods beyond chemisorption: Steady State Isotopic Kinetic Analysis (SSITKA) and Temporal Analysis of Products (TAP), which promise to refine our view of those critical structures by offering chemical characterizations that can resolve population densities of specific structures. This article offers the hypothesis that a Rayleigh distribution may be useful for representing the population of those structures as a function of readily measured domain size. A compelling test of that hypothesis requires experiments that span a wide range of domain sizes. The often-cited popular statistic, that catalysis is involved in >80% of the value added by the chemical industry and thus about 20% of the world’s economy [30], arises largely from how essential catalysis is to the refining of petroleum and abating of pollution caused by combustion of fossil fuels. This statistic will become less stark in the conceivable future when the world forsakes fossil fuels as the predominate source of energy. However, while there will then be a much-diminished demand for petroleum refining catalysts, there will still be a need for understanding the catalysis in: • the production of chemicals and novel, highly engineered materials (e.g., battery separator membranes) • energy conversion (electrocatalysis, photocatalysis) • light water nuclear reactors (viz. passive autocatalytic recombiners [31]) • production and reforming of renewable fuels and energy carriers (e.g., Fischer-Tropsch catalysis of synthesis gas ex CO2 and water; formic acid or ammonia (HCOOH → H2 + CO2; NH3 → N2 + 3 H2) • emission control catalysts (combustion of even renewable fuels produces criterion pollutants: NOx, CO, unburned hydrocarbons) Those applications represent a continued need to augment our command over the basic science of catalysis, likely for new reactions that may involve process conditions significantly different from those encountered in the refining of petroleum or obviating air pollutants. Therefore, we will still long have the need to devise and debate methods for counting sites, mapping the surfaces of heterogeneous catalysts, and normalizing reaction rates. Fortunately, advances in microscopy and catalyst synthesis offer the possibility of testing (and improving) on the notions discussed above. coredata.dc:description: A Rayleigh distribution of particles exposing (1 1 1) surface populations is consistent with the particle size dependence of the turnover rates of the electrochemical reduction of dioxygen catalyzed by a platinum cathode.
coredata.dc:title: Lies, damned lies, and turnover rates
